article.title: The JCMT Transient Survey: Identifying Submillimetre Continuum Variability over Several Year Timescales Using Archival JCMT Gould Belt Survey Observations

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the dashed line in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The average noise level in the Transient Survey data.
The standard deviation of the relative flux calibration factor.
The relative flux calibration factor between the GBS and Transient Survey data.
The difference in peak brightness between protostars and disk objects.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the points labeled "c" represent?
choices: Known variable candidates.
Sources with associated known protostars.
Sources with associated known disk objects.
Calibrators chosen in both the GBS and Transient Survey data.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of plotting the ratio of GBS to Transient Survey peak brightness against the mean Transient Survey peak brightness?
choices: To identify potential variable candidates by their deviation from the average ratio.
To show the correlation between source brightness and variability.
To demonstrate the accuracy of the relative flux calibration.
To compare the noise levels in the GBS and Transient Survey data.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the Î´ value represent?
choices: The relative flux calibration factor between the GBS and Transient Survey data.
The difference between a source\'s peak brightness ratio and the weighted mean, normalized by the uncertainty.
The change in peak brightness divided by the difference between the average GBS and Transient Survey observation dates.
The distance between a source peak and the nearest known protostar.
The relative flux calibration factor between the GBS and Transient Survey data.
The change in peak brightness divided by the difference between the average GBS and Transient Survey observation dates, normalized to the average Transient Survey peak brightness.
The difference between a source\'s peak brightness ratio and the weighted mean, normalized by the uncertainty.
The distance between a source peak and the nearest known protostar.
